Original References

r01 Reference 01

r01 :: a

R. S. Bird. An introduction to the theory of lists. In M. Broy, editor, Logic of Programming and Calculi of Discrete Design, volume 36 of NATO ASI Series F, pages 3-42. Springer-Verlag, New York, NY, USA, 1987. Technical Monograph PRG-56.

PDF: https://www.cs.ox.ac.uk/files/3378/PRG56.pdf

r02 Reference 02

r02 :: a

G. E. Blelloch. Prefix sums and their applications. In J. E. Reif, editor, Synthesis of Parallel Algorithms. Morgan Kaufmann Publishers Inc., San Francisco, CA, USA, 1993.

PDF: http://www.cs.cmu.edu/~guyb/papers/Ble93.pdf

r03 Reference 03

r03 :: a

M. I. Cole. Algorithmic Skeletons: Structural Management of Parallel Computation. MIT Press, 1989.

PS.GZ: http://www.dcs.ed.ac.uk/home/mic/skeletonbook.ps.gz

r04 :: a

r05 :: a

r06 :: a

r09 Reference 09

r09 :: a

r10 Reference 10

r10 :: a

A. Morihata, K. Matsuzaki, Z. Hu, and M. Takeichi. The third homomorphism theorem on trees: Downward & upward lead to divide-and-conquer. In Proceedings of the 36th ACM SIGPLAN-SIGACT Symposium on Principles of Programming Languages, POPL 2009, Savannah, Georgia, USA, January 21-23, 2009, pages 177-185. ACM, 2009.

PDF: http://research.nii.ac.jp/~hu/pub/popl09.pdf

r11 :: a

K. Morita, A. Morihata, K. Matsuzaki, Z. Hu, and M. Takeichi. Automatic inversion generates divide-and-conquer parallel programs. In J. Ferrante and K. S.
